sentence: It’s a big week for retailers.

Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT), American Eagle (AEO), Home Depot (HD), Best Buy (BBY), Dick’s Sporting Goods (DKS), and Staples (SPLS) are just some of the national retail companies reporting earnings this week.
As always, individual results may vary, but when all is said and done, I suspect a clear trend will have emerged from the week’s barrage of numbers.
Already, there is evidence of the way that tend is running with the news that Ascena Retail Group (ASNA) is buying Ann Inc. (ANN).
For those who are unaware, Ascena is the company behind mass market retailers such as Dress Barn and the teeny/tweeny store Justice, while Ann Inc. is the holding company for Ann Taylor and Loft.

Obviously, just as one swallow doth not a summer make so one takeover doesn’t equate to a trend, but after several years when the play in retail has been to buy at the top end, this deal and this week’s results could mark the reversal point.
There are several reasons to suspect that discount retailers could be about to catch up with their snootier cousins.
Firstly, several of those cousins are beginning to show signs of the bull run coming to an end.
Tiffany (TIF) and Michael Kors (KORS) have been down for a while, and Nordstrom (JWN) and Williams Sonoma (WSM) have begun a gradual decline over the last few months.
It is not that results at any of these stores have been particularly bad; it’s just that after several years of strong gains expectations have gotten a little overblown.
Some kind of pullback was inevitable.

The effect of missing those estimates is exaggerated by the fact that that pullback came at a time when conventional wisdom said that retailers should be doing better - after all, weren't we all enjoying more cash in our pockets due to low gas prices?
Well yes, but that difference is marginal at best for high end consumers.
The real effect is on the Wal-Mart and Target shopper.
For them, any saving on fuel costs translates directly to more spending money.

It has taken time for that effect to show and it may never be as strong as some expect as the lessons of 2008/9 have been well learned, as using any additional cash to pay down debt or even save a few bucks is a lot more appealing these days.
Even so, purse strings will loosen at some point.
In addition, the larger “big box” stores will benefit more from lower fuel costs simply due to having more trucks on the road.
That isn't the only benefit likely to be reflected in this week’s earnings reports.
The strong dollar that marked much of the last three months is a plus for companies who retail cheaper imports rather than domestically made products.
The discount market is looking more attractive every day.
Even companies that have viewed the discount market with disdain up to this point are showing a desire to enter it.
If anyone had said six months ago that Whole Foods Market (WFM) would be launching a chain of discount stores they would have been laughed at, but that was announced last week.

None of this will come as a surprise particularly, but in most cases the stock of big retailers has still been falling over the last few months as questions have emerged regarding growth in the broader economy.
For the likes of Wal-Mart, however, as long as unemployment is going down and gas prices remain well below last year’s levels, their customers simply have more to spend.
The recent unemployment and hourly wage numbers would suggest that the broader slowdown is coming at the top end of the income scale rather than the bottom.
In other words, the income inequality that most have agreed has been a problem during the recovery is beginning to sort itself out.
If that is the case, then this week’s earnings will reflect that and the mass retailers will be the ones offering positive surprises.
Who knows, within a few months deals like the ASNA and ANN one announced this morning, where a discount retailer essentially takes over a designer brand, could become increasingly common.
The revenge of the discount retailer is under way.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
